holidays.name: Make Your Own Head Day
holidays.description: A delightfully bizarre holiday encouraging people to craft their own 'head' using anything but their actual head ‚Äî think paper, cardboard, or even veggies! It‚Äôs a playful way to explore creativity and humor.
holidays.origin: Originating from an art therapy movement celebrating self-expression through handmade masks and sculptures.
holidays.funFact: Some people have made elaborate heads so detailed that they've been mistaken for actual sculptures in art galleries!

holidays.name: Native American Heritage Month (Continues)
holidays.description: While this is a month-long observance, November 27 often features special events honoring Native American history, culture, and contributions.
holidays.origin: Established officially in 1990 by Presidential Proclamation to raise awareness and honor Native cultures.
holidays.funFact: November is chosen to align with the Thanksgiving period, a pivotal time for reflecting on Native American heritage and history.

holidays.name: International Absinthe Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the famously mysterious and often misunderstood spirit known as absinthe, the 'Green Fairy,' with tastings and parties worldwide.
holidays.origin: Dedicated to absinthe lovers and connoisseurs to promote appreciation of this once-banned drink‚Äôs rich history.
holidays.funFact: Absinthe was banned in many countries in the early 20th century due to myths about its psychoactive effects, but modern science debunked those claims!

holidays.name: Shopping Reminder Day
holidays.description: A cheeky holiday designed to poke fun at the holiday shopping frenzy, reminding people to stop and think before diving into consumer chaos.
holidays.origin: Coined by consumer rights advocates to encourage mindful purchasing before the Black Friday and Cyber Monday madness.
holidays.funFact: On this day, some stores offer quiet shopping hours or donate proceeds to charity to make the experience less stressful.

holidays.name: Buy Nothing Day (Observed late November)
holidays.description: An anti-consumerism protest day encouraging people to refrain from buying anything for 24 hours to raise awareness about overconsumption.
holidays.origin: Started in Canada in 1992 and now observed internationally, usually on the day after Thanksgiving, but sometimes spills into nearby dates like November 27.
holidays.funFact: Buy Nothing Day has inspired dozens of 'free stores' where people exchange goods without money.
